current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To require the Secretary of Health and Human Services to address certain inconsistencies between
			 the
			 self-attested information provided by an applicant in enrolling in a
			 health plan on an Exchange and being determined eligible for premium tax
			 credits and cost-sharing reductions or in being determined to be eligible
			 for enrollment in a State Medicaid plan or a State child health plan under
			 the State Children's Health Insurance Program and the data received
			 through the Federal Data Services Hub or from other data sources.

text.#text:
If applicant information provided by an individual seeking to enroll in a qualified health plan on
			 a State or Federal
			 Exchange contains inconsistencies, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
or the reduced cost-sharing program
			 under
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 36B
			 of
			 the Internal Revenue Code of 1986

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
later determines to be eligible for such programs, shall
			 retroactively receive the benefits of such programs that such individual
			 was eligible to receive for the inconsistency period.

text.#text:
During the inconsistency period, an individual may be enrolled in qualified health plan, but may
			 not participate in the premium assistance credit program under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:

			 cooperates with a request for additional information and whom the

and the reduced cost-sharing program
			 under

text.#text:
the applicant shall re-enroll in a qualified health plan with appropriate and
			 accurate information during the next open enrollment period.

term.#tail:
means differences between the
			 self-attested information provided by an applicant in enrolling in a
			 health plan on an Exchange and being determined eligible for premium tax
			 credits and cost-sharing reductions or in being determined to be eligible
			 for enrollment in a State Medicaid plan or a State child health plan under
			 the State Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP) and the data received
			 through the Federal Data Services Hub or from other data sources,
			 including differences with respect to—

text.#text: coverage under an eligible employer-sponsored plan;
